ACT
37
MANAGEMENT OF MATRIMONIAL PROPERTY
For tasks of regular administration, such as regular maintenance, exploitation and use of things for their regular purpose, it is considered that the other spouse has given his consent, unless the contrary is proven.
For extraordinary administration on real estate or movable property that are entered in public registers, such as changes in the purpose of things, major repairs, additions, upgrades, remodeling, alienation of the whole thing, lease or rent of the whole thing for longer than one year, establishment of a mortgage on the whole thing, pledging movable property, establishing real and personal servitudes, real encumbrances or building rights on the whole thing requires a joint undertaking of work or the written consent of the other spouse with a notarized signature.
The absence of consent for the tasks referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 of this article does not affect the rights and obligations of an honest third party. The spouse without whose consent the extraordinary work referred to in paragraph 2 of this article was undertaken has the right to compensation for damages caused to him by the other spouse.
